person.content:
Please identify the "Person" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Person". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: Organisers hope to get that run in on Saturday morning , conditions permitting , and stage the race later in the day or on Sunday .

Let's think step by step.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Person" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Person".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Person |
| --- |
| Organizers |

The word "Organizers" is the only clear reference to a person or group of people in the paragraph. The other phrases, "Saturday morning" and "later in the day or on Sunday," refer to times of day and a day of the week, not to people.

location.content:
Please identify the "Location" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Location". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: Organisers hope to get that run in on Saturday morning , conditions permitting , and stage the race later in the day or on Sunday .

Let's think step by step.

| Location   |
|------------|
| Saturday morning |
| later in the day or on Sunday |

Please note that the entities identified are "Saturday morning", "later in the day", and "on Sunday", as they are the locations where the run or race is expected to take place. However, these are not traditional location entities, as they refer to time rather than physical places.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Location" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Location".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Location   |
|------------|
| later in the day or on Sunday |

"Later in the day" and "on Sunday" are the only entities that can be considered locations in this context, as they refer to the time and day when the race is expected to take place. "Saturday morning" is not included as it is not the location of the race, but rather the time when organizers hope to get the run in.
